questions.text:
Match the following lymphomas with their cell of origin.

 


	
		
			
			Lymphoma/leukaemia

			a. Memory B-cell
			
		
		
			
			2. Mantle cell lymphoma
			
			
			b. Germinal/post germinal center B cell
			
		
		
			
			3. Hairy cell lymphoma
			
			
			c. Helper T-cell
			
		
		
			
			4. Mycosis fungoides
			
			
			d. Naive B cell
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

Neoplasm

Cell of origin

Description

Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (Statement 1)

Germinal/post-germinal center B cells
  • Most common NHL.
  • Associated with BCL6 gene rearrangement
  • If CLL transforms into DLBCL, it is called Richter's Syndrome.

Hairy cell leukemia (Statement 3)

Memory B cells
  • More common in boys.
  • BRAF V600E Mutation +
  • It presents with massive splenomegaly affecting the red pulp of the spleen.

Mantle cell lymphoma (Statement 2)

Naive B cell
  • Translocation t(11:14).
  • Associated with GIT polyps.
  • Cyclin D1 and SOX11 +ve,

Mycosis Fungoides (Statement 4)

Helper T cells
  • Cutaneous T-cell NHL.
  • presents with erythema and pruritus.
  • If it affects the blood vessels, it is known as Sezary syndrome.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with a three-year history of pruritic, erythematous plaques on his trunk and extremities. Physical examination reveals widespread erythematous patches and plaques with a "cerebriform" appearance. Peripheral smear findings reveal the presence of abnormal lymphocytes with convoluted nuclei and abundant cytoplasm. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mycosis fungoides

Explanation:
The clinical presentation and peripheral findings is consistent with Mycosis fungoides, a Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, characterized by pruritic erythematous patches and plaques.

  • Sezary cells are atypical lymphocytes characterised by their "cerebriform" or convoluted nuclei.
 

Anaplastic Large-Cell Lymphoma

(Option C)

Adult T-Cell Leukemia/Lymphoma

(Option B)

Mycosis Fungoides

(Option A)

Genetic Alterations

ALK gene mutation on chromosome 2

HTLV-1

Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphoma

Age Group

Children or young adults

Adults

Adults

Cell Morphology

Large anaplastic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei and voluminous cytoplasm (Hallmark cells/Doughnut cells)

 

Multilobated nuclei (Cloverleaf or Flower cells)

 

Neoplastic T cells with cerebriform nuclei (Sezary cells)

Common Clinical Features

Soft tissue involvement (mimicking metastatic carcinoma)
  • Skin lesions

  • Hepatosplenomegaly

Hairy cell leukemia (Option D) is a chronic B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder, and peripheral smear findings typically demonstrate the presence of small, Mature lymphocytes with abundant cytoplasm and "hairy" projections.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with persistent fatigue, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia. Peripheral blood smear shows leukocytosis with mature lymphocytes displaying hairy projections. Flow cytometry confirms the presence of CD11c and CD25 positive cells. Which of the following is the most specific biomarker commonly useful in the diagnosis of condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Annexin A1

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings are consistent with Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL). Annexin A1 is a protein specifically expressed on the surface of hairy cells in Hairy Cell Leukemia.

  • It is characterized by a distinctive genetic mutation (BRAF V600E in >90% of cases) and expression of specific B-cell markers
  • Clinical presentation include persistent fatigue, splenomegaly, and pancytopenia and increased susceptibility to infections..
  • Peripheral smear shows Leukocytosis with mature lymphocytes displaying hairy projections. Marrow exhibits diffuse interstitial infiltrates
  • Flow cytometry markers: The cells in HCL typically expressCD19, CD20, surface Ig (usually IgG), CD11c, CD25, CD103, and annexin A1.

CD20 (Option A) is a surface marker present on most B cells and is commonly expressed in a variety of B-cell lymphomas and leukemias. While CD20 can be positive, it is not specific to HCL and is found in many other B-cell neoplasms.

Annexin A5 (Option B) is a protein involved in the cellular processes related to apoptosis and phospholipid binding. It is used as a marker to detect apoptotic cells.

Apolipoprotein A1 (Option D) is a marker for germ cell neoplasms.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male has been complaining of persistent fatigue, recurrent infections, and easy bruising over the past few months. On physical examination, he has a noticeable abdominal mass. A peripheral smear shows the presence of atypical lymphoid cells with cytoplasmic projections, as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is not true regarding the patient's condition?

choices.text: Associated with the BRAF V600E mutation.
Massive splenomegaly is a common clinical feature.
The pathogenesis involves the proliferation of immature myeloid cells
Typically present with fatigue, infections, and pancytopenia.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The pathogenesis involves the proliferation of immature myeloid cells.

Explanation:

The clinical presentation and peripheral smear findings suggest Hairy cell leukemia, which involves abnormal proliferation of Mature B cells.

Mutations

BRAF V600E (Option A ruled out)

Pathogenesis

Mutation of BRAF V600E gene → Activation of the BRAF protein → MAPK/ERK signalling pathway → Uncontrolled proliferation and survival of mature B-cells (Hairy cells).

Clinical Presentation

Presents with fatigue, recurrent infections, easy bruising, (e.g., early satiety, abdominal discomfort), pancytopenia (Option D ruled out) and symptoms related to splenomegaly (Option B ruled out)

Peripheral Blood Findings
  • Hairy cells with round, oblong, or reniform nuclei and pale blue cytoplasm.

Bone Marrow Biopsy Findings
  • Hypocellular or fibrotic marrow with "hairy cells".
  • Fried egg appearance.

Diagnosis
  • Flow cytometry
  • Immunophenotyping
  • Genetic testing for BRAF V600E mutation

Treatment

Rituximab - BRAF inhibitors

Prognosis

Excellent

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly differentiates between Primary Effusion Lymphoma (PEL) and Immunodeficiency-associated Large B-cell Lymphoma?

choices.text: PEL presents with lymphomatous masses in solid organs, while Immunodeficiency-associated Large B-cell Lymphoma presents as effusions.
PEL is associated with EBV , whereas Immunodeficiency-associated Large B-cell Lymphoma is linked to HHV-8.
PEL presents as Effusions and is associated with HHV-8, whereas Immunodeficiency-associated Large B-cell Lymphoma is linked to EBV.
Both are predominantly found in immunocompetent individuals without any viral association.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) PEL presents as Effusions and is associated with (HHV-8), whereas Immunodeficiency-associated Large B-cell Lymphoma is linked to (EBV).

Explanation:

Subtypes of DLBCL:

Characteristic

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy from Bihar presents with a low-grade fever, weight loss, and abdominal pain for the past 2 months. Investigation reveals a mass involving the ileocecal region, with histopathological examination showing a 'starry sky' appearance, immunohistochemistry positive for CD10, CD19, CD20, and BCL6, and FISH indicating a (8:14) translocation involving the MYC gene. This type of presentation is common in which condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma

Explanation:

In the above case, the patient is from a non-endemic region, and the lesion mainly affects the abdomen. Based on the HPE and IHC findings, it is suggestive of sporadic Burkitt’s lymphoma.

  • Burkitt's lymphoma is a highly aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma associated with the translocations of the c-MYC gene on chromosome 8, t(8:14).
  • It has three primary subtypes:
  1. Endemic Burkitt's lymphoma: Commonly affects children in malaria-endemic areas of Africa, often presenting with tumours in the jaw or facial bones. (Option A)
  2. Sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma: More frequently seen in non-endemic regions and usually involving the ileocaecal region and peritoneum. (Option B)
  3. Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma: Found in patients with conditions such as HIV/AIDS or other forms of immunodeficiency. (Option C).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with an axillary mass and complaints of low-grade fever, weight loss, and night sweats for the past 6 months. Histopathological examination (HPE) of a biopsy sample from the mass reveals diffuse follicular growth with centrocytes with cleaved nuclei and centroblasts. Immunohistochemistry shows BCL2 stain positive, CD19, CD20, and CD10 positive, and CD5 negative. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Follicular lymphoma

Explanation:
The given scenario, along with HPE and IHC, is consistent with Follicular lymphoma, which is associated with BCL2- gene translocation; t(14:18)

  • Follicular lymphoma (FL) is a malignant neoplasm originating from germinal center B-cells, characterized by the t(14;18) translocation leading to overexpression of BCL2.
  • Clinically, it presents with painless lymphadenopathy and may include systemic symptoms.
  • Histopathologically, FL exhibits a nodular growth pattern with centrocytes(Small cells with cleaved nuclei and scanty cytosol) and centroblasts(Larger cells with open nuclear chromatin, several nucleoli)
  • Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for CD10/19/20, BCL2, and BCL6, and negativity for CD5.
  • Management focuses on palliative approaches due to its indolent but incurable nature.


 

Follicular hyperplasia (Option A) is benign, featuring reactive B cell proliferation in lymph nodes with preserved architecture, characterized by CD10/20 positivity and absence of BCL2 expression.

Mantle cell lymphoma (Option B) Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for Cyclin D1, CD19, CD20, surface immunoglobulins (usually IgM and IgD), and CD5, but CD23 is negative and HPE shows small lymphoid cells with irregular nuclear outlines, condensed chromatin, and scanty cytoplasm

Burkitt’s lymphoma (Option D) Histopathological examination reveals numerous mitotic and apoptotic cells, nuclear remnants phagocytosed by benign macrophages with abundant clear cytoplasm, creating a characteristic "starry sky" pattern. Immunohistochemistry shows positivity for IgM, CD19, CD20, CD10, and BCL6, but negativity for BCL2.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy presents with a large mass over the mandible. On the HPE of the lesion, a ‘starry sky pattern’ is seen, similar to the image below. This condition is associated with which of the following genetic abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) MYC gene

Explanation:
The clinical presentation with mandibular mass and a starry sky appearance on HPE are characteristic of Burkitt’s lymphoma, which is associated with the translocation of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, thus leading to overexpression of the MYC protein.

  • All forms of Burkitt’s lymphoma (Endemic, Sporadic and HIV associated) are associated with such translocations.
  • The most common translocations are t (8:2), t(8:14), and t(8:22).

BCL2 gene (Option B) translocation is associated with follicular lymphoma. The most common is t(14;18), leading to the juxtaposition of the IGH locus (Ch 14) with the BCL2 locus(Ch 18), leading to overexpression of BCL2.

Cyclin-D1 (Option C) gene translocation is associated with all mantle cell lymphoma. There is a translocation of the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 and IGH locus on chromosome 14; t(11;14), which results in overexpression of cyclin D1, thus promoting G1 to S-phase progression in the cell cycle.

BCL6 gene (Option D) dysregulation is associated with Diffuse large B cell lymphoma. It can occur due to translocations or promoter sequence mutations of the BCL6 gene on Chr. 3q27.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with painless swelling of the neck, intermittent fever, night sweats and significant weight loss over the past three months. On examination, enlarged cervical and mediastinal lymph nodes are noted. A biopsy reveals the presence of characteristic cells, as shown in the image below. Which of the following about the described condition is NOT true?

choices.text: More often localised to a single axial group of nodes
Typically, it spreads in a contiguous manner.
Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring involvement are rare.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Extranodal presentation is common

Explanation:
The given clinical scenario and histopathological findings suggest a diagnosis of Hodgkin lymphoma, and the HPE reveals the presence of characteristic Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

  • Hodgkin lymphoma typically spreads in an orderly, contiguous manner from one lymph node group to the next adjacent group without skipping areas.

 

Feature

Hodgkin Lymphoma (HL)

Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL)

Age of presentation

Bimodal distribution peaks in young adults (15-35 years) and older adults (over 55).

More common in older adults but can occur at any age.

Localisation

More often localised to a single axial group of nodes (cervical, mediastinal, para-aortic) (Option A)

More frequent involvement of multiple peripheral nodes

Pattern of Spread

Orderly spread by contiguity

Non Contiguous spread (Option B)

Involvement of Mesenteric Nodes and Waldeyer Ring

Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are rarely involved. (Option C)

Waldeyer ring and mesenteric nodes are commonly involved.

Extranodal Presentation

Extranodal presentation is rare.

Extranodal presentation is common. (Option D)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman came with complaints of chronic fatigue and a palpable nodular mass in her axilla. Further investigations reveal a B-cell neoplasm. Which of the following is the least likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Anaplastic large cell lymphoma

Explanation:

Anaplastic Large-cell lymphoma is a type of peripheral T-cell lymphoma, not a B-cell neoplasm.

WHO classification of lymphoid neoplasm

1. Precursor B-cell neoplasm

B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (B-ALL)

2. Peripheral B-cell neoplasm

  • Chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma
  • B-cell prolymphocytic leukemia
  • Lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma
  • Splenic and nodal marginal zone lymphomas
  • Extranodal marginal zone lymphoma
  • Mantle cell lymphoma
  • Follicular lymphoma (Option A)
  • Marginal zone lymphoma (Option B)
  • Hairy cell leukemia (Option C)
  • Plasmacytoma/plasma cell myeloma
  • Diffuse large B-cell lymphoma
  • Burkitt lymphoma

3. Precursor T-cell neoplasm

T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia/lymphoma (T-ALL)

4. Peripheral T-cell and NK-cell neoplasms

  • T-cell prolymphocytic leukemia
  • Large granular lymphocytic leukemia
  • Mycosis fungoides/Sézary syndrome
  • Peripheral T-cell lymphoma, unspecified
  • Anaplastic large-cell lymphoma (Option D)
  • Angioimmunoblastic T-cell lymphoma
  • Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma
  • Panniculitis-like T-cell lymphoma
  • Hepatosplenic γδ T-cell lymphoma
  • Adult T-cell leukemia/lymphoma
  • Extranodal NK/T-cell lymphoma
  • NK-cell leukemia

5. Hodgkin's lymphoma

  • Classic subtypes
    • Nodular sclerosis
    • Mixed cellularity
    • Lymphocyte-rich
    • Lymphocyte depletion
  • Nodular lymphocyte predominant

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with painless swelling of multiple lymph nodes in his neck and groin. He denies experiencing fever, night sweats, or weight loss. Physical examination reveals bilateral cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Based on the Ann Arbor classification, what is this patient's most likely stage of disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Stage III

Explanation:

Based on the Ann Arbor classification, Stage III involves lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm , corresponding to the presentation of bilateral cervical and inguinal lymphadenopathy in this patient.

Clinical Staging of Hodgkins Lymphoma (Ann Arbor Classification)

STAGE

DISTRIBUTION OF DISEASE

I

Involvement of a single lymph node region (I) or a single extra lymphatic organ or site (IE).

II

Involvement of two or more lymph node regions on the same side of the diaphragm alone (II) or localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site (IIE).

III

Involvement of lymph node regions on both sides of the diaphragm without (III) or with (IIIE) localised involvement of an extra lymphatic organ or site.

IV

Diffuse involvement of one or more extra lymphatic organs or sites with or without lymphatic involvement.

 

All stages are further divided based on the absence (A) or presence (B) of the following symptoms: unexplained fever, drenching night sweats, and/or unexplained weight loss of greater than 10% of normal body weight.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with painless enlargement of cervical lymph nodes, accompanied by fever, night sweats, and weight loss. Biopsy reveals large, atypical cells with prominent nucleoli and a mixed inflammatory background. Immunohistochemical staining shows these cells are negative for CD15 and CD30. Which marker is most likely to be positive in these cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) CD20

Explanation:

Predominant (Non-Classical) Hodgkin Lymphoma:

  1. Histological Features: Predominant (Non-Classical) Hodgkin Lymphoma is characterised by large, atypical cells with prominent nucleoli and a mixed inflammatory background.
  2. Immunophenotype: The atypical cells in this subtype typically lack expression of CD15 and CD30 but are positive for CD20 and CD45 markers, distinct from classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
  3. Clinical Presentation: painless lymphadenopathy, fever, night sweats, and weight loss, similar to classical Hodgkin lymphoma
  4. Prognosis: overall survival rates may be lower compared to classical Hodgkin lymphoma.
  5. Epidemiology: Less common than classical Hodgkin lymphoma and may occur in younger and older adults.

CD3 (Option B) is a marker of mature T lymphocytes and is not typically expressed by the large, atypical cells seen in Predominant (Non-Classical) Hodgkin’s lymphoma

CD15 and CD 30 (Option C) and (Option D) are markers commonly expressed on Reed-Sternberg cells in classical Hodgkin's lymphoma but is typically negative in predominantly (Non-Classical) Hodgkin’s lymphoma

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of HIV presents with fever, night sweats, and weight loss. A lymph node biopsy was done. Immunohistochemical staining shows these cells are CD15 and CD30 positive but CD20 negative. He was diagnosed with Lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin's lymphoma. Which of the following features is characteristic of lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) High number of Reed-Sternberg cells

Explanation:

Lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin's lymphoma

  • Histological Features: LDHL is characterised by a scarcity of lymphocytes and many pleomorphic, often bizarre Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells. The cellular environment is typically rich in fibrosis or necrosis.
  • Immunophenotype: The RS cells in LDHL are usually positive for CD15 and CD30 but negative for CD20.
  • Clinical Presentation: systemic symptoms such as fever, night sweats, and significant weight loss referred to as "B symptoms.”
  • Epidemiology: LDHL is the least common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma and is more frequently diagnosed in older adults and individuals with HIV infection.
  • Prognosis: LDHL is associated with a poorer prognosis compared to other Hodgkin lymphoma subtypes due to its more aggressive nature
  • Treatment: Treatment typically involves a combination of chemotherapy and, in some cases, radiation therapy..

Presence of fibrous bands (Option A) it is characteristic of nodular sclerosis Hodgkin's lymphoma, not LDHL. Nodular sclerosis is marked by the presence of fibrous bands that divide the lymph node into nodules.

 

Abundance of reactive lymphocytes (Option B) it is typical of lymphocyte-rich Hodgkin's lymphoma, a subtype characterised by an abundance of small, reactive lymphocytes and relatively few Reed-Sternberg cells.

 

Predominance of nodular growth pattern (Option D) it is associated with nodular lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin's lymphoma (NLPHL), not LDHL. It is characterised by a nodular growth pattern and the presence of "popcorn" or lymphocyte-predominant cells,

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents with painless lymphadenopathy in the cervical region. A biopsy reveals the presence of numerous small lymphocytes with scattered large mononuclear Hodgkin and Reed-Sternberg cells, which are CD20 positive and CD15/CD30 negative. Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is most consistent with these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Lymphocyte-rich Hodgkin lymphoma

Explanation:

Nodular Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma;

  • Histological Features: Nodular Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma is characterised by a predominance of reactive lymphocytes with relatively few Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells.
  • Immunophenotype: The RS cells are typically positive for CD20 and negative for CD15 and CD30, distinguishing it from other subtypes of Hodgkin lymphoma.
  • Clinical Presentation: Patients often present with painless lymphadenopathy, commonly in peripheral lymph nodes rather than mediastinal involvement.
  • Prognosis: This subtype generally has a favourable prognosis compared to other types of Hodgkin lymphoma due to its lower aggressiveness and higher responsiveness to treatment.

Nodular sclerosis Hodgkin lymphoma (Option A) is the most common subtype, characterised by the presence of lacunar Reed-Sternberg cells and fibrous bands that divide the lymphoid tissue into nodules. These cells are usually positive for CD15 and CD30 but negative for CD20.

Mixed cellularity Hodgkin lymphoma (Option B) features a heterogeneous mixture of cells, including Reed-Sternberg cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, neutrophils, and plasma cells. These cells are typically CD15 and CD30 positive but negative for CD20.

Lymphocyte-depleted Hodgkin lymphoma (Option D) is the least common subtype and is characterised by a paucity of lymphocytes and a high number of pleomorphic, often bizarre Reed-Sternberg cells. These cells are usually CD15 and CD30 positive but negative for CD20 and associated with a poorer prognosis

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with painless swelling of multiple lymph nodes, fever, night sweats, and weight loss. A biopsy of the affected lymph node reveals the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells. Which of the following options regarding Mixed cellularity type Hodgkin’s Lymphoma is not true?

choices.text: It is characterised by frequent mononuclear and diagnostic Reed-Sternberg (RS) cells.
RS cells in this subtype typically express CD15 and CD30.
More than 70% of cases are Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) positive.
It is usually associated with a better prognosis than other subtypes of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) It is usually associated with a better prognosis than other subtypes of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Explanation:

Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin’s Lymphoma often presents at an advanced stage (III or IV), which is generally associated with a worse prognosis compared to the Nodular Sclerosis subtype, which typically presents at an earlier stage (I or II) and has a relatively better prognosis.

  • Mixed-Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma (MCHL) accounts for 20% to 25% of cases and features lymph nodes diffusely effaced by a heterogeneous cellular infiltrate, including T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages, along with abundant Reed-Sternberg and mononuclear variants. (Option A)
  • Approximately 70% of Reed-Sternberg cells are EBV-positive. (Option B)
  • RS cells are CD15+, CD30+ (Option C)
  • MCHL is more prevalent in males and is more likely to be associated with systemic symptoms such as night sweats and weight loss.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female presents with painless swelling in her neck and shortness of breath. Imaging studies reveal a large mediastinal mass. A biopsy of the lymph node shows frequent lacunar cells and Reed-Sternberg cells. The RS cells are positive for CD15 and CD30 and usually negative for EBV. Which subtype of Hodgkin's lymphoma is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Nodular Sclerosis Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma
 

Explanation:
The given clinical scenario points towards diagnosing Nodular Sclerosis type of Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma which features characteristic Lacunar variant Reed-Sternberg cells and collagen deposition in lymph nodes.

  • Its background includes T cells, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages, with occasional diagnostic Reed-Sternberg cells, which express PAX5, CD15, and CD30.
  • Spread may involve spleen, liver, and bone marrow, infrequently associated with Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Occurring equally in males and females, it commonly affects lower cervical, supraclavicular, and mediastinal lymph nodes in adolescents or young adults and has an excellent prognosis.

Nodular Lymphocyte-Predominant Hodgkin Lymphoma (Option B) is characterised by a background of follicular dendritic cells and reactive B cells, with frequent lymphocyte-rich (Popcorn cell) variants, typically does not express CD15 or CD30 and is usually EBV-negative.

Lymphocyte-Rich Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma (Option C) is characterised by a background infiltrate rich in T lymphocytes, with frequent mononuclear and diagnostic RS cells. RS cells of this type typically express CD15 and CD30 and are usually EBV-negative.

Lymphocyte-Depleted Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma (Option D) has a paucity of background reactive cells and frequent diagnostic RS cells. RS cells in lymphocyte-depleted classical Hodgkin lymphoma typically express CD15 and CD30 and are usually EBV-positive. It often presents with advanced disease.

questions.text:
Match the following


	
		
			
			Cells
			
			
			Histopathology
			
		
		
			
			A) Popcorn cells
			
			 
			
			1)

			
			
		
		
			
			B) Lacunar cells
			
			
			2)

			
			
		
		
			
			C) Mononuclear cells
			
			
			3)
			
		
		
			
			D) Reed-sternberg cell
			
			
			4)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) A- 2, B-4, C-1, D-3

 

Explanation:

 

Histopathological variants of Hodgkin’s Lymphoma

Description

Mononuclear cells

  • Single nucleus with a large, inclusion-like nucleolus with abundant cytoplasm.

  • Seen in Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma

Popcorn cells
  • Cells with multiple infolded nuclear membranes, small nucleoli, fine chromatin, and abundant pale cytoplasm.
  • Seen in Nodular lymphocyte - Predominant Hodgkin lymphoma.

Reed-sternberg cell

It is characterised by two nuclear lobes, large inclusion-like nucleoli, and abundant cytoplasm and is typically surrounded by lymphocytes, macrophages, and an eosinophil.

Lacunar cells

 

  • Typically found in the nodular sclerosis subtype.

  • Nuclei are more delicate, folded, or multilobate.

  • Abundant pale cytoplasm often gets disrupted during sectioning, creating an appearance where the nucleus sits in an empty space (lacuna).

questions.text: In the WHO classification of Hodgkin lymphoma, which marker is typically expressed in classical Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CD15

Explanation:

The CD15 marker is typically expressed by Reed-Sternberg cells in classical Hodgkin lymphoma, aiding in its identification and diagnosis.

WHO Classification of Hodgkin lymphoma:

1. Classical Hodgkin Lymphoma (CHL)

  • Nodular Sclerosis Hodgkin Lymphoma
  • Mixed Cellularity Hodgkin Lymphoma
  • Lymphocyte-Rich Hodgkin Lymphoma
  • Lymphocyte-Depleted Hodgkin Lymphoma
